body:
Did this yesterday.

On desktop you can now see counts of upvotes and downvotes on posts. These numbers are fuzzed by +/- 1%, rounded up (ex. 1-100 votes are fuzzed +/- 1 vote, 101-200 votes are fuzzed +/- 2 votes, etc)

![](https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/730807967707824259/739659496082636851/image.png?width=1026&height=577)

I also implemented the infrastructure to do the same with comments, I just have to figure out how we want to display it. (Working on this part was how I broke comment voting yesterday)

body:
That was my initial idea too (probably most people), but I feel like that's a bit messy and confusing. I proposed a change on to the admins on github that shows it this way instead:

![](https://i.imgur.com/ABS4cFF.png)

(note: that's an image, not an embedded comment lol)

It looks cleaner and doesn't get in the way of things. Displaying "extra" information is exactly what that bar is for, so the number of upvotes/downvotes fits there perfectly.

body:
I don't know what you're doing or how you're doing it, being a mere user, which in computer-speak means it's all my fault due to "user error." In any case, I do know that my "comment score" lost 42 points this morning with no evident changes on individual comments. This "karma/rep" thing is problematical in a bunch of ways, starting with the perverse incentives for brigading, groupthink, and rep whoring. Not only that, but the actual counts seem to bounce around like hail in a thunderstorm, with only a tangential relationship to my activity. 

I appreciate your work on all of this, but let's be charitable and say you have a lot more work to do before I can consider even the totals reliable, let alone on the policy side of things. The weird thing is that I personally care about this karma/rep thing only because the net total is used as threshold levels for permitted activities here. So I've watched the numbers, and once you watch the numbers it's hard to turn off the light, so to speak. The net totals make less and less sense to me.

body:
You've explained the counting mechanism before, and I accepted that, but the unexplainable fluctuations remain. I feel for the challenges you face, and mention this part mainly in the interest of reliability. The number, regardless of what it is, should be reliable and consistent, and it does not appear to be. I'll refrain from the broader policy questions for now and focus on the count, which sad to say I cannot trust at this point.

Blame it on my background as someone who had two careers where the numbers really mattered, especially in the second career as a securities analyst where getting the data right was right smack at the core of that profession. So, for better or for worse, even though it doesn't matter all that much (I used to caution my employees about the danger of "false precision") to me personally, I'll forever be a numbers guy. It's baked into my lizard brain, and that won't change.

You need to get this right. It's a matter of confidence, and all the more so given that you've set some net "karma/rep" point thresholds here.

I'll refrain from the broader policy questions for now and focus on the count, which sad to say I cannot trust at this point.

Blame it on my background as someone who had two careers where the numbers really mattered, especially in the second career as a securities analyst where getting the data right was right smack at the core of that profession. So, for better or for worse, even though it doesn't matter all that much (I used to caution my employees about the danger of "false precision") to me personally, I'll forever be a numbers guy. It's baked into my lizard brain, and that won't change.

You need to get this right. It's a matter of confidence, and all the more so given that you've set some net "karma/rep" point thresholds here.

post.body:
Did this yesterday.

On desktop you can now see counts of upvotes and downvotes on posts. These numbers are fuzzed by +/- 1%, rounded up (ex. 1-100 votes are fuzzed +/- 1 vote, 101-200 votes are fuzzed +/- 2 votes, etc)

![](https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/730807967707824259/739659496082636851/image.png?width=1026&height=577)

I also implemented the infrastructure to do the same with comments, I just have to figure out how we want to display it. (Working on this part was how I broke comment voting yesterday)
